newsitem.title: UK: Super-charged UK Treasury misfires in cyberspace.
newsitem.headline: Super-charged UK Treasury misfires in cyberspace.

text.p: Britain's Treasury Department -- enacting changes at a breakneck pace -- misfired into cyberspace on Wednesday by releasing an erroneous figure on interest rates.

Financial markets were puzzled, the Treasury Department was red-faced and the central bank could be forgiven for smirking at a super-charged Labour government, in power for just three weeks after 18 years in opposition and hell-bent on change.
Indeed, the mishap on rates came on the same day that the central bank issued its first ever warning about the dangers of conducting financial affairs on the Internet.
In its annual report, the Bank of England said it welcomed increased choice for customers as more institutions offer banking services on the worldwide computer network.
But it said cowboys may abuse the system and consumers might not always be able to tell if the institution was authorised or from where it was operating.
Caution was its watchword -- an word apparently not recognised by some newcomers in the finance ministry.

For when the Treasury released minutes on Wednesday of crucial talks between the finance minister and Bank of England governor, it muddled its numbers and had to admit the old-fashioned paper version of events was the one to be trusted, not the sleek new Internet version.
"The printed version shows (Bank of England Governor Eddie George) asked for a quarter point rise and that is correct," said a Treasury spokesman.

The Internet version had said that George favoured a half-point rise -- much to the shock of some traders since degrees of a percent can amount to millions lost or gained in the hurly-burly of world financial markets.
Said one embarrassed Treasury insider: "Oh no. This is terrible. I'll have to go and kick the machine."
